newsitem.title: ROMANIA: BUCHAREST BOURSE GETS TWO NEW FIRST-TIER LISTINGS.
newsitem.headline: BUCHAREST BOURSE GETS TWO NEW FIRST-TIER LISTINGS.

text.p: The Bucharest stock exchange said on Monday another two companies would join in trading this week bringing to six the number of four-tier stocks and to 40 the total number of listings.
Sofert SA state-owned fertiliser maker will join the bourse on Tuesday, while Arctic SA state-run refrigerator maker will be traded starting on Wednesday, an exchange statement said.
It said Sofert, based in the north-eastern town of Bacau, had a share capital of 71.6 billion lei, in shares with a nominal value of 25,000 lei each.
Sofert's main stockholder is the State Ownership Fund (FPS) with a 69.99 percent stake. An investment company holds 12.3 percent and individual shareholders have the rest.
Sofert had a 1996 net profit of 8.8 billion lei, up from 1.9 billion the previous year. It paid a dividend worth 1,228 lei per share last year, up from 261.8 lei per share in 1995.

Arctic, based in Gaesti, 80 km (50 miles) north-west of Bucharest, has a share capital of 57.2 billion lei in shares with a face value of 1,000 lei each. The FPS holds 50.99 percent of Arctic, the company manager has 0.01 percent and the rest is held by individual shareholders, including employees.

Last year, Arctic had a net profit of 11.6 billion lei, up from 9.8 billion in 1995. The 1996 dividend per share was 74.4 lei per share, the statement said. Arctic paid a dividend of 1,560 lei per share in 1995, when its shares were 25,000 lei worth each before a split.
Current first-tier listings on the Bucharest bourse include Azomures fertiliser maker, Oltchim chemical plant and pharmaceuticals companies Antibiotice and Terapia. The second tier lists 34 stocks.
Brokers welcomed the newcomers, saying it would increase share liquidity and would also help raise capital inflows.
"Local and foreign investors have shown a clear preference for first-tier listings in our market, so I am positive capital liquidity will increase," said a trader. ($=7,110 lei)
